review.title: CP-nets: A Tool for Representing and Reasoning withConditional Ceteris Paribus Preference Statements
review.abstract: Information about user preferences plays a key role in automated decision making. In many domains it is desirable to assess such preferences in a qualitative rather than quantitative way. In this paper, we propose a qualitative graphical representation of preferences that reflects conditional dependence and independence of preference statements under a ceteris paribus (all else being equal) interpretation. Such a representation is often compact and arguably quite natural in many circumstances. We provide a formal semantics for this model, and describe how the structure of the network can be exploited in several inference tasks, such as determining whether one outcome dominates (is preferred to) another, ordering a set outcomes according to the preference relation, and constructing the best outcome subject to available evidence.

metadata.title: CP-nets: A Tool for Representing and Reasoning with Conditional Ceteris Paribus Preference Statements

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: A central goal in the study of computerized decision support is to design tools that enable the preferred selection process to be either partially or fully automated. Methods of extracting, displaying, and thinking about the preferences of naïve users are particularly important in AI applications used by collaborative © 2004 AI Access Foundation and Morgan Kaufmann Publishers. All rights reserved. Filtering (Lashkari, Metral, & Maes, 1994) and recommendation systems (Nguyen & Haddawy, 1998) requires user preferences. In many of these applications, users may not have the patience (or sometimes the ability) to provide detailed preference relationships or usage features.

sections.heading: 2. Model Definition
sections.text: The philosophical treatment of many intuitive qualitative predictions of preference began in 1957 in a pioneering work by Hallde "n (1957) and was continued by Castan" eda "(1958), Wright (1963, 1972), Kron and Milovanovic" (1975), Trapp (1985) and Hansson (1996). The reason for such intensive analysis of these predictions finds its succinct expression in the opening of Hansen's (1996) essay: When discussing with my wife which table we should buy for our living room, I said, "A round table is better than a square table." By this I did not mean that any round table, regardless of its other characteristics, is better than any square table. Rather, I meant that any round table is better (for our living room) than any square table that does not significantly differ in its other characteristics, such as size, type of wood, finish, price, etc. That is the preference paribus or "everything else."

sections.heading: 2.1 Preference Relations
sections.text: We focus our attention on single-step decision problems with complete information, ignoring in this paper all questions arising from multi-step sequential decision analysis and any consideration of risks arising in the context of uncertainties. (We assume that the world may be in a number of states where there are a number of actions that can be taken.) Each action that is taken in a state has a specific outcome (we do not concern ourselves with uncertainty about the impact or knowledge of the state). The amount of all results is determined by O. A preference ranking is a total preference ranking over the totality of results: o1 o2 means that the result is o1 o1 o2 o2 o2. We use o1 o2 o2 to state the fact that the result is o2 o2 o2 o2 o2.

sections.heading: 3. Outcome Optimization
sections.text: One of the main characteristics of CP networks is that with a CP-NetN we can easily determine the best result among the preference rankings that satisfy N. We refer to such a query as a query to optimize results. This proves to be a simple task in CP networks.

sections.heading: 3.1 An Algorithm for Outcome Optimization
sections.text: Intuitively, in order to achieve an optimal result, we simply have to sweep through the network from top to bottom (i.e., from ancestor to descendant) and set each variable to its preferred value. In fact, while the network generally does not set a unique ranking, it determines a unique best result (assuming that there is no indifference). More generally, we assume that we have evidence that restricts possible outcomes in the form of an instantiation z − n of a subset Z V of network variables. Determining the best completion of z vi (i.e., the best result consistent with z) can be achieved in much the same way as we are now using it. Outcome optimization queries can be answered with the following forward-looking procedure, with the number of variables being temporally linear. sections.heading: 4.4 Complexity of Dominance Queries for Binary-valued, Acyclic CP-nets
sections.text: In this section, we analyze the complexity of dominance tests with respect to binary-rated CP networks and show a link between the structure of the CP-net graph and the worst complexity of dominance queries. In particular, we show that: • If a binary-rated CP network forms a directed tree, the complexity of dominance tests is square in the number of variables. • If a binary-rated CP network forms a polytree (i.e., the induced undirected graph is acyclic), dominance tests are polynomic in size of the CP network description. • If a binary-rated CP network is connected individually (i.e., there is at most a directed path between any node), dominance tests np-complete. The problem remains hard even if a node in the network is limited by a low constant. • Dominance tests for binary-rated CP networks remain a problem that is solved by CP sharing.

sections.text: However, DGs without cycles in the underlying undirected graphs, also known as polytrees, provide minimal extension of directed trees. Unfortunately, the TreeDT procedure for polytree CP meshes is not complete unless it is extended with some form of traceability (even if it is limited to binary variables) due to the fact that several parents of a particular node are allowed to flip their values, but only one of the choices can lead to the target result, while the others lead to a dead end. sections.heading: 4.4.4 Intractable dominance queries
sections.text: While the dominance check for binary-rated, polytree CP networks is polynomic, we can show that for binary-rated, directional paths individually connected to CP networks, this problem is np-complete.9 This can be demonstrated by a CP-net-oriented extension of the evidence for the corresponding claim in relation to planning problems. (Brafman & Domshlak, 2003) These results also imply that dominance tests for binary-rated CP networks remain in np if the number of unique paths between each pair of nodes in the CP network is polynomically bundled. (Theorem 15 dominance tests for binary-rated, directional CP networks is np-complete.) Proof: For detection see Appendix A. Immediate expansion of directional paths in the CP networks is inevitably bundled.

sections.heading: 5. Search Techniques for Dominance Queries
sections.text: In the previous section, we have shown that dominance testing is generally difficult even for binary-rated CP meshes, and that tractable algorithms exist only for specific problem classes. In this section, we will discuss the search for Flipping9. While each polytree is directly connected individually, the opposite is not true. sections.heading: 5.2 Least-Variable Flipping
sections.text: The extension of the suffix rule is the least variable flipping rule, defined as follows: Suppose we have a CP net N, and a query N, and this is one of the least improvable variables in the world, if there is any value that Xi (Xj) must specify, and no descendant of Xj in the world has this property. Intuitively, one of the least improvable variables in the world is one that can be the lowest in the world to produce a result that is preferred. Of course, there may be several such variables. We say Xj is the least improbable in terms of the target o iff Xj is the least noticeable variable among those that are not part of a suffix rule with o.

sections.heading: 5.3 Forward Pruning
sections.text: In a search procedure for an improved flip sequence, whether or not this approach adopts the above heuristics, one can apply a general approach that has a number of desirable properties: (a) it often quickly shows that no flip sequence is possible; (b) it fails to reduce the number of variables to reduce the number of preference rules for each variable; (c) there is no compromise as to the size of the largest variable domain; and (d) it is relatively cheap: its time complexity is O (nrd2), where n is the number of variables, r is the maximum number of preference rules for each variable, and d is the general idea is to sweep forward through the network, pruning all values of a variable that cannot appear in an improved flip sequence.

sections.heading: 6. Incompletely Specified Preferences and Indifference
sections.text: The only case not analyzed by Domshlak and Brafman is the correctness of the TreeDT procedure for "extended" CP planning.

sections.heading: 7. Concluding Remarks
sections.text: In this thesis, we introduced CP networks, a new graphical model for displaying qualitative preference arrangements that reflects the conditional dependence and independence of preference statements in the context of ceteris paribus semantics. This formal framework provides a compact and arguably natural representation of preference information and allows us to efficiently answer some of the most important forms of preference requests. We described several types of queries and algorithms for answering them in relation to a specific CP network. In particular, it was shown that result optimization and result arrangement techniques can be solved in a temporally linear manner in relation to the number of variables in the network. However, in the case of dominance queries, the situation is more complicated. First, we demonstrated the equivalence of answering dominance queries with the task of the existence of an improving (or deteriorating) sequence of variable value changes in relation to the given CP network. Subsequently, we reduced the latter task to a specific search for a sub-class of general insights that we are using for several possible subclassifications in the structure.

sections.heading: 7.1 Applications
sections.text: One such application - preferential driven adaptive multimedia presentation - was recently developed at Ben-Gurion University (Domshlak et al., 2001; Gudes et al., 2002).We have described the key components of this system in Section 3.2. Another application where both conceptual and computer-specific properties of CP networks appear to be useful is a distributed meeting planner. A basic prototype for such a system was implemented at Bengurion University (Brafman & Domshlak, 2001).We are expanding this system while working on the related theoretical problem of multiagent optimization.

sections.heading: 7.2 Related Work
sections.text: A number of lines of research relate to CP networks. In addition to the conceptual work in philosophy and philosophical logic described in Section 2, in AI, Doyle and Wellman (1991, 1994), ceteris paribus assertions and their logical properties are examined. However, it is not clear whether useful questions can be answered within this framework, and in particular graphic representations of preference statements are not taken into account. To get the most out of our knowledge, there are no computer-based results for this formalism. Therefore, it is not clear whether useful questions can be answered within this framework. On the surface, CP networks are reminiscent of Bayean networks (Pearl, 1988), which also include graphical structures that capture conditional claims of independence. Indeed, Bayesian networks and their use of probable independence provide important motivation for our work, but the two structures differ significantly from each other.

sections.heading: 7.3 Future Work
sections.text: In fact, most of them are able to play by the rules that they need for their work, and they are able to play by the rules that they need for their work.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: Some parts of this paper appeared in C. Boutilier, R. Brafman, H. Hoos and D. Poole, "Reasoning with Conditional Ceteris Paribus Preference Statements," Proceedings of the Fifteenth Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence, pp. 71-80, Stockholm, 1999; and in C. Domshlak and R. Brafman, "CP-nets - Reasoning and Consistency Testing," Proceedings of the Eighth International Conference on Principles of Knowledge Representation and Reasoning, pp. 121-132, Toulouse, 2002. Thanks to Chris Geib for his contributions on earlier, related models of CP networks and to the anonymous speakers for their many useful suggestions. Boutilier, Hoos and Poole were supported by the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council and the Institute for Robotics and Intelligent Systems. Brafman appreciates the support of the Paul Ivanier Center for Robotics Research and Production.

referenceMentions.context: Preference elicitation is a complex task and is a key focus of work in decision analysis (Keeney & Raiffa, 1976; Howard & Matheson, 1984; French, 1986), especially elicitation involving non-expert users.

CP-nets can be used to specify different types of preference relations, such as a preference ordering over potential decision outcomes or a likelihood ordering over possible states of the world, for example, as in Shoham’s (1987) preference semantics.

Philosophical treatment of many intuitive qualitative preferential statements began in 1957 in a pioneering work of Halldén (1957), and was continued by Castañeda (1958), von Wright (1963, 1972), Kron and Milovanović (1975), Trapp (1985), and Hansson (1996).

We note that reasoning about ceteris paribus statements has been explored in AI (Doyle et al., 1991; Wellman & Doyle, 1991; Doyle & Wellman, 1994), though not in the context of network representations or exploiting preferential independence in a computational fashion.

Acyclic CP-nets are shown to be effective and natural in the above-mentioned work on web page presentation (Domshlak et al., 2001), as well as in a related project that deals with the presentation of multi-media content in a medical domain (Gudes, Domshlak, & Orlov, 2002)—a more extensive example from this latter domain is presented in the next section.

Recently, initial results on consistency testing for cyclic CP-nets were presented by Domshlak and Brafman (2002a). In particular, a wide class of cyclic, binary-valued CPnets was identified to be efficiently testable for consistency.
Applications based on this system for the presentation of web-based content and multi-media medical data were recently presented by Domshlak et al. (2001) and Gudes et al.

Applications based on this system for the presentation of web-based content and multi-media medical data were recently presented by Domshlak et al. (2001) and Gudes et al. (2002). Through this example we demonstrate the simplicity of preference specification using CP-nets, the utility of acyclic networks, and the use of the optimization algorithm described above.

The planning problem over multi-valued variables with discrete, finite domains is known to be pspace-complete (Bäckström & Nebel, 1995), and it remains pspace-complete under the assumption that all the variables are binary (Bylander, 1994) (i.
Second, we introduce the notion of a causal graph (Knoblock, 1994), a directed graph whose nodes stand for the problem variables.

Therefore, in our computational analysis of dominance queries for binary-valued acyclic CP-nets we can use some of the results and techniques of Brafman and Domshlak (2003).

Adopting the terminology of Domshlak and Shimony (2003) and Shimony and Domshlak (2002), a directed acyclic graph G is directed-path singly connected if, for every pair of nodes s, t ∈ G, there is at most one directed path from s to t.

Adopting the terminology of Domshlak and Shimony (2003) and Shimony and Domshlak (2002), a directed acyclic graph G is directed-path singly connected if, for every pair of nodes s, t ∈ G, there is at most one directed path from s to t.
An algorithm is adapted from the corresponding algorithm for planning problems with binary variables, unary operators, and polytree causal graphs described by Domshlak and Brafman (2003).
An algorithm for the latter problem is presented by Brafman and Domshlak (2003), and the time complexity of this algorithm is O(22κn2κ+3), where κ is the maximal in-degree of the causal graph.

An algorithm for the latter problem is presented by Brafman and Domshlak (2003), and the time complexity of this algorithm is O(22κn2κ+3), where κ is the maximal in-degree of the causal graph. Recall our assumption that the in-degree of the CP-net is bounded by some constant (in this case, κ). This assumption is justified as the CPTs are part of the problem description, and the size of a CPT (X) is exponential in |Pa(X)|. Therefore, the complexity of the algorithm of Brafman and Domshlak (2003) on CP-nets is polynomial in the size the CPnet.
Proof: The theorem is immediately entailed by the corresponding result for planning of Brafman and Domshlak (2003); for the proof in terms of CP-nets, see Appendix A.

A complementary result with respect to these graphs (Domshlak, 2002b), namely recursively directed hypercubes, shows that dominance queries with respect to binary-valued, acyclic CP-nets with unbounded node in-degree may require flipping sequences of size exponential in n, where n is the number of variables in the CP-net.

A CP-net based search algorithm by Boutilier et al. (1997) was specifically designed to address this problem. For the description of this algorithm, as well as for analysis of its computational properties we refer the reader to Boutilier et al. (1997), Brafman and Domshlak (2001).

A CP-net based search algorithm by Boutilier et al. (1997) was specifically designed to address this problem. For the description of this algorithm, as well as for analysis of its computational properties we refer the reader to Boutilier et al. (1997), Brafman and Domshlak (2001).
On the surface, CP-nets are reminiscent of Bayesian networks (Pearl, 1988), which are also graphical structures capturing conditional independence assertions.
Motivated by the same considerations driving our work, Bacchus and Grove (1995) and La Mura and Shoham (1999) study different notions of independence and their associated graphical representations.
Motivated by the same considerations driving our work, Bacchus and Grove (1995) and La Mura and Shoham (1999) study different notions of independence and their associated graphical representations.

Motivated by the same considerations driving our work, Bacchus and Grove (1995) and La Mura and Shoham (1999) study different notions of independence and their associated graphical representations. Both representations allow for quantitative assessments, unlike CP-nets (at least in their current form) and differ from CP-nets in the precise nature of the independence concept studied. In particular, Bacchus and Grove concentrate on the notion of conditional additive independence. Additive independence is a very strong property, requiring that the utility of an outcome be the sum of the “utilities” of the different variable values of the outcome. Conditional additive independence is a weaker requirement, and thus more promising in practice. Bacchus and Grove show that the conditional additive independence properties of a domain can be captured by an undirected graph where for set of nodes A,B,C, A is independent of B given C if C separates between the nodes in A and B. La Mura and Shoham (1999) define the concept of u-independence using a ceteris paribus comparison operator over utilities.

Motivated by the same considerations driving our work, Bacchus and Grove (1995) and La Mura and Shoham (1999) study different notions of independence and their associated graphical representations. Both representations allow for quantitative assessments, unlike CP-nets (at least in their current form) and differ from CP-nets in the precise nature of the independence concept studied. In particular, Bacchus and Grove concentrate on the notion of conditional additive independence. Additive independence is a very strong property, requiring that the utility of an outcome be the sum of the “utilities” of the different variable values of the outcome. Conditional additive independence is a weaker requirement, and thus more promising in practice. Bacchus and Grove show that the conditional additive independence properties of a domain can be captured by an undirected graph where for set of nodes A,B,C, A is independent of B given C if C separates between the nodes in A and B. La Mura and Shoham (1999) define the concept of u-independence using a ceteris paribus comparison operator over utilities. This operator measures the “intensity” of preference for specific values of certain variables given some fixed value for the other variables and with respect to a fixed reference point. They also define an undirected graphical structure, expected utility networks, in which u-independence is represented using the notion of node separation. Finally, recent work by Benferhat, Dubois and Prade (2001) provides a preliminary investigation of the potential of possibilistic logic in qualitative decision analysis, and more specifically in qualitative preference representation.

Motivated by the same considerations driving our work, Bacchus and Grove (1995) and La Mura and Shoham (1999) study different notions of independence and their associated graphical representations. Both representations allow for quantitative assessments, unlike CP-nets (at least in their current form) and differ from CP-nets in the precise nature of the independence concept studied. In particular, Bacchus and Grove concentrate on the notion of conditional additive independence. Additive independence is a very strong property, requiring that the utility of an outcome be the sum of the “utilities” of the different variable values of the outcome. Conditional additive independence is a weaker requirement, and thus more promising in practice. Bacchus and Grove show that the conditional additive independence properties of a domain can be captured by an undirected graph where for set of nodes A,B,C, A is independent of B given C if C separates between the nodes in A and B. La Mura and Shoham (1999) define the concept of u-independence using a ceteris paribus comparison operator over utilities. This operator measures the “intensity” of preference for specific values of certain variables given some fixed value for the other variables and with respect to a fixed reference point. They also define an undirected graphical structure, expected utility networks, in which u-independence is represented using the notion of node separation. Finally, recent work by Benferhat, Dubois and Prade (2001) provides a preliminary investigation of the potential of possibilistic logic in qualitative decision analysis, and more specifically in qualitative preference representation. The possibilistic approach takes utilities into account, as well as probabilities, but provides a qualitative approach to decision problems by replacing numeric preferences and probabilities with linear orderings. For discussion of this approach to utilities and preference representation, see Benferhat et al. (2001), Dubois, Godo, Prade, and Zapico (1998b), Dubois, Berre, Prade, and Sabbadin (1998a), Dubois, Prade, and Sabbadin (1997), and for related qualitative models, see Boutilier (1994), Tan and Pearl (1994).

A number of recent papers have started to deal with this question, with some interesting insights and results (Domshlak, 2002a; Domshlak & Brafman, 2002a; Brafman & Dimopoulos, 2003; Domshlak, Rossi, Venable, & Walsh, 2003).

This has been explored in the context of CP-nets with quantitative information (Boutilier et al., 2001); it remains to be seen how to use such techniques in a purely qualitative setting.

metadata.abstractText: Information about user preferences plays a key role in automated decision making. In many domains it is desirable to assess such preferences in a qualitative rather than quantitative way. In this paper, we propose a qualitative graphical representation of preferences that reflects conditional dependence and independence of preference statements under a ceteris paribus (all else being equal) interpretation. Such a representation is often compact and arguably quite natural in many circumstances. We provide a formal semantics for this model, and describe how the structure of the network can be exploited in several inference tasks, such as determining whether one outcome dominates (is preferred to) another, ordering a set outcomes according to the preference relation, and constructing the best outcome subject to available evidence.
